analyzed: paṭṭhāna pakaraṇa  dhamma paccanīya anuloma tika duka paṭṭhāna pāḷi

original: 22.14. Kusalattika, Niyataduka🔽Nakusalaṁ naniyataṁ dhammaṁ paccayā kusalo niyato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā …. Hetuyā cha …pe… avigate cha.🔽Nakusalaṁ naaniyataṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca abyākato aniyato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā.
analyzed: kusalattika  na kusalam na niyatam dhammam paccayā kusalaḥ niyataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā hetuyā cha pe avigate cha  na kusalam na aniyatam dhammam paṭicca abyākataḥ aniyataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā
translated: The reverse order of the law of conditionality, the text of the Paṭṭhāna according to the method of the Triads and Dyads🔽From a profitable and an unfixed state arises a profitable and a fixed state, by way of root-cause condition. … In six ways, … in six ways, … in six ways.🔽From a profitable and an unfixed state arises an indeterminate and an unfixed state, by way of root-cause condition.

original: Naakusalaṁ naaniyataṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca abyākato aniyato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā.🔽Naabyākataṁ naaniyataṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca abyākato aniyato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā.🔽Nakusalaṁ naaniyatañca naabyākataṁ naaniyatañca dhammaṁ paṭicca abyākato aniyato
analyzed: na akusalam na aniyatam dhammam paṭicca abyākataḥ aniyataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā  na abyākatam na aniyatam dhammam paṭicca abyākataḥ aniyataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā  na kusalam na aniyatam ca na abyākatam na aniyatam ca dhammam paṭicca abyākataḥ aniyataḥ
translated: From an unprofitable and an unfixed state arises an indeterminate and an unfixed state, by way of root-cause condition.🔽From an indeterminate and an unfixed state arises an indeterminate and an unfixed state, by way of root-cause condition.

original: dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Naakusalaṁ naaniyatañca naabyākataṁ naaniyatañca dhammaṁ
analyzed: dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā na akusalam na aniyatam ca na abyākatam na aniyatam ca dhamma
translated: From a profitable and an unfixed state and an indeterminate and an unfixed state arises an indeterminate and an unfixed state, by way of root-cause condition. From an unprofitable and an unfixed state and an indeterminate and an unfixed state arises an indeterminate and an unfixed state, by way of root-cause condition.

original: paṭicca abyākato aniyato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā pañca,
analyzed: paṭicca abyākataḥ aniyataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā pañca
translated: A conditionally-arisen indeterminate-indeterminate thought arises with root-cause condition. (Condensed.) With root-cause as condition, five.
With predominance as condition, five. … With non-disappearance as condition, five.
